entry.content:
More about Ewelina Siudzi≈Ñska in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Ewelina Siudzi≈Ñska
Location (City, Country): Katowice, Poland
Occupation: SAP Consultant (BW & BI)

 

 


Ewelina, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

My family says I am hard-working and determined. My friends say I am well-organized and reliable. I think I am just authentic and myself. Most the time, I go against the flow! I do not listen to music that everyone else listens to, and I do not spend my holidays on a sunbed with an all-inclusive package. Instead, I choose  conscious travelling with every hour of sightseeing planned out üòâ and as much physical activity as possible. I try to keep a good work-life balance. My work and personal development are very important to me, and I spend a lot of time working towards my goals. But living my own life is also important to me. Sports such as fitness, cycling, walking, and swimming help me achieve this on an ordinary day. I enjoy reading crime novels, and when I do not have time for that, I listen to audiobooks while doing other daily activities. I love cooking and enjoy trying new flavors during my travels.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I work as SAP BI and BW consultant. I specialize in designing and implementing operational and strategic reports. These are primarily activities aimed at working closely with functional teams to understand reporting needs and deliver solutions that meet business objectives. The icing on the cake is the creation of interactive dashboards in SAC based on models I built in SAP BW. I collaborate on system upgrades, enhancements, and migrations. My tasks also entail maintaining extractors from SAP ERP, but also deploying standard and custom extractors from the S/4HANA system. This involves collaborating with teams responsible for handling subscribers‚Äô queues.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

Since 2019, I have been building the SAP Community in Silesia, in Katowice. I invested a significant amount of my personal time in this, but it was worth it! Currently, our Katowice Community: https://community.sap.com/t5/katowice/gh-p/katowice is a strong group of specialists who enjoy each other's company. It has always been my idea to surround myself with SAP experts and feel even more motivated to act in my region. That is why becoming an SAP Champion was a natural next step. I am grateful for being nominated to the Community of SAP Champions. I would like to get to know all of you and, in time, be able to say: ‚ÄúYes, I know this person, he/she is a specialist in ... with whom I had the opportunity to talk/work together on organizing an event / etc.‚Äù


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

When I am looking for an idea to solve a problem, I always browse https://community.sap.com/ to see if anyone else has done something similar. I often find inspiration there, and sometimes it opens my mind to a different solution than I had planned.

Besides, I believe that the best way to learn from the SAP Community is through conversation. That is why I am initiating meetings in the region to enable people with different experiences in SAP to meet and talk. It always broadens horizons and often allows everyone to learn from others.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

The SAP Community is made up of wonderful people. It would be great to have the opportunity to meet in person, especially those who are heavily involved in the Community. I think that at least once a year, SAP should organize and sponsor such a meeting for SAP Champions and Mentors. This would give us the opportunity to get to know each other, exchange experiences, expand our cooperation and much more.

My second suggestion is to develop a prestigious program for speakers at events, which would give them greater recognition and benefits. As an organizer of SAP meetups and meetings, I encounter obstacles in finding speakers for the events I have organized and plan to organize in the future. It is not that there are not any specialists! There are many specialists in the region, but few people are willing to volunteer their time to prepare presentations and lectures. This can be easily changed by following the example of other companies that have a strong community around their product, such as Microsoft. Or create your own program in which SAP would reward the commitment of speakers.

Ewelina's question to you:
What do you think about my suggestions above to get the most out of SAP Community?
Feel free to write whether you agree with those and share your opinion.

entry.title: Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition contains enhancements to popular AI features and new natural language interaction options that help you work more intelligently and intuitively.

We‚Äôve spent the past 6 months since the 2502 release working with your feedback ‚Äì from beta programs, to roundtable discussions in the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum, to one-on-one meetings with customers ‚Äì to learn how we can help you achieve more with the help of AI in your system. Let‚Äôs take a look at what‚Äôs new, update you on the commercialization of some features, and give you resources for getting involved with our upcoming beta program. 

Natural language filtering now supports a wider range of queries

The AI-assisted easy filter (first released in 2502) enables you to filter list reports in your SAP Fiori elements-based apps using natural language. This simplifies how you access the information you need and reduces the training time required to pick up new applications delivered by SAP.

AI-assisted easy filter enables natural language filtering of pages with lists of business objects. Here the user can filter for a given sold-to party using plain language rather than needing to know its key..

For 2508, we‚Äôve made a number of enhancements to make interactions with AI-assisted easy filter even more intuitive:

  1. Tables can be filtered without needing to know an object‚Äôs specific key. Instead, simply enter the name of the object you are looking for. The AI-assisted easy filter will map that text to the intended key and apply it to the filter fields for you, which is a much more natural way to search for information. In the event that there are multiple keys with similar names, you will receive results filtered for those names. As before, you can always refine your results in the input field or using the classic filtering.
  2. We‚Äôve also worked to ensure parity between the filter fields that can be applied using the AI-assisted easy filter and the classic filter bar. Some users had reported that, in some cases, AI-assisted easy filter would not apply queries to certain filters. This was caused by the fact that some of the filter fields used navigation paths to different entities instead of the main entity for the app. This scenario is now supported and you can filter on any property present in the classic filter bar.

My Home Personalization with Insights Cards supports more apps and a new way to query for cards

The ability to create Insights cards and quickly add them to My Home now supports 20 SAP Fiori apps.

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards was released as a Joule capability as part of its 2503 release. The functionality allows end users to query Joule for business data they regularly need using natural language. The output is displayed as a card that can be added to their My Home page for easy reference. This makes it easier for users to access information they need to make everyday business decisions and move processes forward.

This functionality was initially limited to 9 applications. With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, this coverage has been extended to 11 additional applications. This gives users easier and wider access to the business data that is important to them. AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards now supports the following applications:

  1. Find Maintenance Order
  2. Find Maintenance Order and Operation
  3. Maintain Bill Of Material
  4. Manage Business Partner Master Data
  5. Manage Customer Returns
  6. Manage Manual Reservations
  7. Manage Material Coverage (Version 2)
  8. Manage Outbound Deliveries
  9. Manage Product Master Data
  10. Manage Purchase Orders (Version 2)
  11. Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional
  12. Manage Sales Orders
  13. Manage Sales Orders - Version 2
  14. Manage Sales Quotation - Version 2
  15. Manage Supplier Master Data
  16. Manage Usage Decisions
  17. Material Documents Overview
  18. Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  19. Reproceess Failed Material Movements
  20. Supplier Invoices List (Version 2)

Users can now use natural language to create and add Insights Cards directly in My Home.

For the 2508 release, we have also introduced a new way to create Insights cards using natural language: you can access the feature directly from My Home. This gives users the flexibility to choose the personalization option that works best for them, giving them access to the information they need at a glance.

If you'd like to read even more exciting updates about features and functionality included in the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, check out the following fantastic blogs from my colleagues:

  • For a general overview of new functionality: Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release 
  • For a few more AI uses cases, some focused on particular business processes: Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 

Commercialization update: New Base AI includes common AI functions at no additional cost

For the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a number of AI solutions have been added to its Base AI offering. This means that you can use the features absolutely free of charge. You simply need to sign the SAP AI terms here and SAP will handle the activation for you.

Included in the Base AI offering for this release are AI-assisted easy filter and AI-assisted smart summarization, as well as AI-assisted enterprise search (which allows you to look up data from the search in My Home). Give them a try!

Try out upcoming AI innovations in the 2508 beta

For customers looking to try out the absolute latest in AI innovations, registration for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta is still open. This is your opportunity to try out and give feedback on new use cases for AI in your system. The solutions up for beta testing are free to use for the duration of the program.  Below is a preview of some of the features that will be available. Please note: Customer/partner participation will be at the discretion of the Beta Testing Program team. Participants must use SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition productively. Future developments are at the discretion of SAP and their details and delivery dates may be changed at any time.

Resolve situations directly in My Home without navigating to applications

AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home allows you to quickly take action on business processes that need your attention directly in My Home..

The Situations tab in My Home provides quick summaries of business processes that need to be addressed in your system. Previously, this meant reading the alert on the tile, navigating to the required app(s), and making the required changes. With AI-assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home, we‚Äôre streamlining how you take action on these scenarios. You‚Äôll now be able to see a summary of the situation, start the relevant business process from quick actions on the card, and even make changes to the business data all without leaving your My Home page. This allows you to stay on top of your business and resolve potential issues even faster.

Streamline data entry in object pages

AI-assisted easy fill streamlines data entry by populating object pages based on natural language input (for example: emails or messages from colleagues).

Depending on your business scenario, SAP Fiori object pages can sometimes be quite complex. Data entry might mean filling a field at the top of the screen, scrolling for several sections to add more information, and so on. AI-assisted easy fill enables you to enter your updates into a single field using natural language. The solution then maps your input to the proper fields, highlights any potential inconsistencies that may need to be addressed, and ‚Äì after your review ‚Äì updates the fields. This will help speed up data entry and reduce training time for new users.

Resolve error messages with AI assistance

AI-assisted error explanation provides resolution recommendations to error and warning messages in your system.

Learning new business processes can be tricky. AI-assisted error explanation uses AI to generate explanations and suggest resolutions for errors that are triggered in your system. This streamlines how you handle errors and reduces training time, making you more productive and helping you pick up processes even faster; in addition to reducing your organization‚Äôs support load.

Search for applications you need using natural language

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications allows you to search for applications using natural language.

When learning a new business process or stepping into a new role, it can sometimes be challenging to find the exact application you need to carry out a task. With AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications, you can search for the app you need using natural language. Simply type in what you need to do and get served the required application, which you can add to your My Home page with a single click. This allows you to access the applications you need without needing to know the exact application name.

We want to hear from you!

Whether you take advantage of the new free features in the Base AI package, subscribe to cutting edge technologies, or choose to take part in a beta program; we want to hear what you think about these solutions! Give them a try and share your feedback below or with the product team. Your experience is critical to understanding how we can make these innovations even better for you.

When you‚Äôre ready to get involved, you can:

  1. Register to use base AI features
  2. Sign up for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta
  3. Join the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum (for customers live on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

Happy experimenting! We‚Äôll be back with another update for the 2602 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: Investment Boost: A significant step to promote economic growth
entry.content:
Co-Authors: @frank_afeaki and @olga_lazareva 

The New Zealand government has taken a significant step towards promoting economic growth with the launch of the "Investment Boost" initiative in Budget 2025.  This major tax incentive allows businesses to instantly deduct 20% of the cost of new assets, in addition to their regular depreciation. This substantial change is set to reduce tax liabilities and enhance cash flow, thereby empowering businesses to invest and grow.

While this news is undoubtedly welcome, it also presents the technical challenge of integrating this incentive into existing SAP Finance systems. Businesses must now adapt their asset accounting process to ensure they can fully leverage the benefits of the "Investment Boost" while maintaining compliance and operational efficiency. 

To take advantage of this tax benefit, our customers are required to post the 20% instant depreciation in addition to the regular depreciation. The key challenge here is to achieve the 20% immediate depreciation from the capitalization date while continuing regular depreciation.

For this special scenario, we chose to use the depreciation type 'special depreciation'. This type of depreciation allows for percentage depreciation and is commonly used for tax purposes. Using this depreciation type, in phase 1 we can apply a 20% special depreciation, which depreciates the asset by 20%. After this, phase 1 will continue with regular depreciation and depreciate based on the asset's useful life. However, the regular depreciation will now start with a net book value that is 20% less than the actual cost.

  • Phase 1: Special depreciation to post 20% of Investment Boost on the date of capitalization
  • Phase 1: Continue phase 1 with the regular depreciation, based on useful life, where reference value is Acquisition and Production Costs (APC) minus 20% special depreciation

To configure the keys, we need 2 different multi-level methods. The first multi-level method (IBS) is designed to cater to the 20% special depreciation, while the second method (IBR) is designed for regular depreciation.

Multilevel method for Special depreciation - IBS

Multilevel method for Special depreciation - IBR

Let's proceed to the configuration of the necessary depreciation keys. 

Sample Key for declining method:

Sample Key for straight line method:

We have tested the scenarios detailed below using the new investment boost depreciation keys, but we recommend that you perform your own testing to confirm that your results are as expected.

1. Investment boost posting with special depreciation key

The test was successful, with the 20% investment boost posted under special depreciation and the asset continued to depreciate based on useful life, with a reference value of APC minus 20% special depreciation. Example screenshot of the 20% investment boost posted with acquisition:

2. Subsequent additional acquisitions

The test was successful, result of test was the expected result. Example screenshot of additional acquisition:

3. Partial intra-company transfers and partial retirement

Unfortunately, this test was not successful, and the investment boost was doubled. Example screenshot of the partial intra-company transfer:

To overcome the issues with the partial transfers and partial retirement, we had to design a new depreciation key, in this example NIMD which allowed for no additional special depreciation posting during transfers and retirement. To achieve this, we propose a workaround based on time intervals which would fix these inconsistencies. 

Key points to remember here are:

  • The depreciation key NIMD is designed with a special depreciation phase with base method 23 which allows for no additional special depreciation during partial transfers and retirement.
  • Needs to be assigned to both the sender and the receiver asset.
  • Works from the beginning of the period and does not provide scope for changes in between the period.

Sample depreciation key for partial transfers and retirement:

Screenshot of changing the asset depreciation key to the NIMD depreciation key using time intervals on the asset as well as the successful partial intra-company transfers.

Sending asset - intra-company transfer:

Receiver Asset - intra-company transfer: 

4.  Subsequent qualifying investment boost acquisition against existing assets:

This scenario is relevant for assets that were acquired before the investment boost period.  Here, you cannot change to the investment boost depreciation key using time interval as you will more likely get the error message "AA591: Depreciation key has more depreciation types than the previous deprec. key".

See the screenshot below using the Investment boost straight line depreciation key NIBS

As a workaround, we propose you create an asset sub-number of the original asset using the investment boost depreciation key and book the acquisition against the new asset sub number.

Conclusion

In summary, the implementation of the new investment boost scheme offers a powerful opportunity for businesses to benefit from significant tax incentives and enhanced cash flow. However, maximizing these advantages will require the configuration of new multi-level depreciation keys to incorporate the investment boost requirements.  Creating and using the new multi-level investment boost depreciation keys will meet the main requirements, but a work around is required to handle scenarios such as a partial intra-company and partial retirements, as described above. By configuring the workaround described above, which involves a time interval adjustment on the asset, organizations can ensure accurate compliance and optimize their use of the investment boost. Diligent testing and thoughtful setup are essential for successfully navigating these complexities and securing the full benefit of this government initiative.

entry.title: Custom Sales Blocklist in SAP Business One
entry.content:
Abstract

How can we block specific items for certain customers in SAP Business One? Unchecking the "Saleable" field in the Item Master Data will block the item for all customers, but what if we want to give clients the option to choose which items are not saleable for each customer during a specific period? The solution is to define a Sales Blocklist table in the system and use an SQL stored procedure to prevent sales forms from recording restricted data.

Steps

  1. User-Defined Tables ‚Äì Setup
  2. User-Defined Fields ‚Äì Management
  3. Modifying Stored Procedure in the Database
  4. Filling Out the Designated Table
  5. Sales Documents

1.  User-Defined Tables ‚Äì Setup

To create tables in SAP Business One, follow this path and create the Sales Blocklist table:

Tools ‚Üí Customization Tools ‚Üí User-Defined Tables ‚Äì Setup

üí°For an auto-generated numeric key, set Object Type to No Object with Auto Increment; this automatically fills the Code column. Moreover, there would be no risk of duplicate keys and no need for custom numbering logic.

2.  User-Defined Fields ‚Äì Management

To create columns in the User-Defined Fields Management form:

Tools ‚Üí Customization Tools ‚Üí User-Defined Fields ‚Äì Management

üí°After the table is saved, SAP Business One adds it to Tools ‚Üí User-Defined Windows.

3.  Modifying Stored Procedure in the Database

Modify SBO_SP_TransactionNotification in the selected database.

IF _type = '17' AND @transaction_type IN ('A', 'U') -- Sales Order 
BEGIN
    DECLARE @CardCode NVARCHAR(50), @DocDate DATE
    DECLARE @BlockedItems NVARCHAR(MAX) = ''

    SELECT @CardCode = CardCode, @DocDate = DocDate FROM ORDR WHERE DocEntry = _of_cols_val_tab_del

    SELECT @BlockedItems = STRING_AGG(T0.ItemCode, ', ')
    FROM RDR1 T0
    INNER JOIN [@SALESBLOCKLIST] T1 
      ON T1.U_CustomerCode = @CardCode  
      AND T1.U_ItemCode = T0.ItemCode
    WHERE T0.DocEntry = _of_cols_val_tab_del
      AND @DocDate BETWEEN T1.U_FromDate AND T1.U_ToDate

    IF @BlockedItems IS NOT NULL AND @BlockedItems <> ''
    BEGIN
        SET  = 1001
        SET _message = N'Selling these items to this customer on this date is not allowed: ' + @BlockedItems
    END
END

  The code above applies the blocklist logic to Sales Orders. For the complete script, which extends this validation to other documents like Deliveries and A/R Invoices, please see the full version on GitHub.

4.  Filling Out the Designated Table

Fill the table manually or by copying data from Excel spreadsheets. Open the created table from the menu and fill it up for the specific restrictions.

 

5.   Sales Documents

In the following step, use a Sales documents like Sales Order by selecting a specific customer and items.

Now, when we select items for the specific customer that is on the Sales Blocklist table, we will see an error that forbids the user from selecting these items.

Conclusion

This method is a useful way to restrict the sale of specific items to certain customers for a defined period of time in SAP Business One. For the blocking logic itself, several alternatives can also be very effective. These include using the B1 Usability Package (a third-party add-on) or adding a User-Defined Field (UDF) at the row level with a Formatted Search for real-time validation. Additionally, for managing large volumes of restriction data, using the Data Transfer Workbench (DTW) for bulk uploads can be a useful tool for larger implementations.

 

Prepared by

Amirhossein Tonekaboni

SAP Business One ERP Consultant

entry.title: Supercharge your view of Connected Business Partners
entry.content:
Introduction

It‚Äôs a common headache in SAP Business One: a company shows up in both ledgers‚Äîvendor and customer‚Äîand the net position isn‚Äôt obvious during day-to-day work. In SAP Business One, link the two records using the 'Connected Customer/Vendor' field in BP Master Data (Accounting) so the relationship is explicit in the system. Once the records are linked, the standard tools‚ÄîDunning, Aging, and Internal Reconciliation‚Äîbecome much more useful for seeing the combined relationship. The foundational aspects of handling these dual-role scenarios are valuable topics within the SAP Business One community. This article provides practical tips to enhance your control over these relationships.

In practice, most teams want faster, on‚Äëform visibility and safeguards. Here's what actually delivers that. This article delves into practical custom enhancements you can implement in SAP Business One. We'll cover how to empower users through:

  • Adding dynamic User-Defined Fields (UDFs) with live balance queries to critical forms like Outgoing Payments.
  • Implementing automated alerts to stay informed about key connected BP statuses.
  • Introducing transaction validations (via SBO_SP_TransactionNotification) to prevent issues, such as unnecessary payments to vendors who are also indebted to us as customers.

Connecting Business Partners

To link a customer and a vendor in SAP Business One, you can use the 'Connected Customer/Vendor' field within the accounting tab in Business Partner Master Data.

üí°    The [ConnBP] database field in the OCRD table (Business Partner Master Data table) stores this link, and connect two distinct BP records.

Connected Vendor/Customer field in BP Master Data


Standard SAP Business One Tools for Managing Connected BPs

1.    Dunning Wizard: This tool can be configured to consider the connected relationship, providing a comprehensive report for both the primary BP and its connected counterparts by selecting the relevant options in the Dunning Wizard.

Dunning Wizard for connected BPs

2.    Customer/Vendor Aging Reports: These reports can also display all related documents for connected business partners, offering a unified view.

Customer/Vendor Aging Reports

3.    BP Internal Reconciliation: After reviewing the status of connected BPs (e.g., via Aging Reports or your custom query), the Internal Reconciliation feature can be used. While standard internal reconciliation typically applies to transactions within a single BP account, understanding the consolidated picture can guide manual journal entries or offsetting transactions that effectively reconcile the net position between a connected customer and vendor when submitting financial documents.

BP Internal Reconciliation

Internal Reconciliation

Going Beyond Standard Tools: Custom Enhancements for Superior Control

Beyond the built‚Äëin functions, a few small customizations can give you tighter control in daily business:

1.    Custom Queries for Real-time Tracking & Proactive Alerts: You can create specific SQL queries to get an immediate overview of these relationships. This query can then be added to a user's 'My Menu' for quick access.

SELECT
    V.CardCode,
    V.CardName,
    C.CardCode,
    C.CardName,
    C.Balance AS CustomerBalance,
    V.Balance * -1 AS VendorBalance,
    V.Balance + C.Balance AS NetBalance
FROM OCRD V
INNER JOIN OCRD C ON V.CardCode = C.ConnBP
WHERE V.CardType = 'S' AND C.CardType = 'C'
ORDER BY V.CardCode;

üîó    This query provides a real-time snapshot of vendor-customer balances, aiding decision-making. The full code is on GitHub.

Connected BP Balance Query
Set up the balance query as a scheduled Alert: if the connected customer is overdue beyond your limit and the vendor has a payment due, AP gets a notification.

Setting up alerts for connected BP balances

Messages/Alerts Overview

üí°   For scheduled alerts, ensure the SAP Business One Job Service (Alerts) component is installed and running on your server, and that Alert Management is enabled in General Settings.

2.    Implementing Transaction Validations via Stored Procedure

To prevent potential issues, such as making a large payment to a vendor who, as a connected customer, has a significant overdue balance, you can implement validations directly within SAP Business One transactions.

You can do this by adding a rule in the SBO_SP_TransactionNotification stored procedure: when an Outgoing Payment is added for a vendor, check the connected customer's overdue balance and block it if it's over your set limit. For example, when an Outgoing Payment is being added for a vendor, your stored procedure can check if this vendor has a connected customer account with an overdue balance. Based on predefined conditions (e.g., if the customer's overdue amount exceeds a certain threshold), the procedure can block the payment and display an error message to the user, prompting them to review the consolidated account status before proceeding.

üîó    This way, you avoid paying a supplier who is overdue as a customer. The complete stored procedure is available on GitHub.

Validations via Stored Procedure

3.    User-Defined Fields (UDFs) for Instant Visibility on Forms

Add UDFs on Outgoing Payments and drive them with Formatted Searches so that when a vendor is picked, the connected customer code and both balances appear instantly. When a vendor is selected, these UDFs can automatically display the code of any connected customer and their relevant balances.

Used-Defined Fields - Management

When a vendor is selected on the Outgoing Payment form, if they have a customer linked using the 'Connected Customer' field (in BP Master Data), the UDF for 'Connected BP Code' will auto-populate. Subsequently, other UDFs can display the connected customer's balance and the main vendor's balance using Formatted Searches linked to custom SQL queries.

Outgoing Payments form with UDFs for a linked customer

These UDFs use the Formatted Search feature to automatically fetch and display relevant data via linked SQL queries.

üí°    To assign a Formatted Search to a UDF (or any field), select the field on the form and press 'Alt + Shift + F2'  to open the 'User-Defined Values - Setup' window.

Used-Defined Values

If no customer is connected to the selected vendor, the 'Connected BP Code' UDF will be empty, and the 'Customer Balance' UDF will display zero.

Outgoing Payments Form for a Vendor with No Linked Customer


Conclusion

Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

 

Hello Everyone,

With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the Sourcing and Procurement line of business continues to evolve, bringing forward innovations that empower procurement professionals to operate with greater agility, transparency, and collaboration. This release focuses on enhancing core procurement processes, integrating intelligent technologies, and improving user experience across the board. Let‚Äôs take a closer look at the key updates and how they support your procurement transformation journey.

 

For other releases please see here. Check out all demos in a playlist here.

Operational Procurement

  • Document Management System attachments on the purchase requisition header
  • Ability to provide ad hoc approver for purchase order workflow
  • Reviewer workflow for purchase order approval
  • Enhanced account assignment categories as start conditions for purchase order workflow
  • V4 API for intracompany stock transfer
  • Maintenance of supplier confirmation notes
  • Enable account assignment category Q in Manage Purchase Contracts App
  • Extensibility in manage source lists app
  • Viewing distributed value still to be invoiced in the purchase order items by account assignment app

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

  • Input tax ‚Äì Calculation, verification, and validation using external tax engines

SAP Arabia Central Procurement

  • Enablement of single-line distributions from central purchase contracts
  • Procurement Expansion Package

 

 

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Document Management System attachments on the purchase requisition header

The integration of the Document Management System (DMS) at the header level of purchase requisitions marks a significant improvement in how procurement teams manage documentation. Professional purchasers can now attach relevant documents directly to requisitions, with the ability to classify them for internal or external use. While external classification will be supported in future updates, the current functionality already streamlines documentation processes and ensures consistency across SAP Fiori applications such as ‚ÄúManage Purchase Requisition ‚Äì Professional‚Äù and ‚ÄúCreate Purchase Requisition ‚Äì Advanced.‚Äù This enhancement simplifies audit trails, improves traceability, and fosters better collaboration between procurement teams and stakeholders.

 

For more information, see: Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional

Ability to provide ad hoc approver for purchase order workflow

Procurement workflows often require flexibility, especially when exceptional circumstances arise. The introduction of ad-hoc approvers allows authorized users to dynamically add individuals to a workflow instance based on the context of a specific purchase order. This capability ensures that critical decisions are not delayed due to rigid approval chains. The ability to designate multiple ad-hoc approvers and track their involvement in the approval history adds a layer of transparency and responsiveness, making procurement processes more agile and context-aware.

 

For more information, see:  Manage Purchase Orders 

Reviewer workflow for purchase order approval

SAP has introduced a reviewer step in purchase order workflows, allowing designated users to monitor workflow progress and provide feedback without having approval authority. This feature is particularly valuable for organizations that require compliance checks, financial oversight, or legal reviews before finalizing purchases. By enabling user-based or role-based recipient selection and allowing deadline settings, SAP ensures that the review process is both structured and adaptable. This innovation enhances governance and fosters a collaborative approach to procurement decision-making.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders

Enhanced account assignment categories as start conditions for purchase order workflow

The ability to use account assignment categories‚Äîsuch as Internal Order, Asset, and Sales Order‚Äîas workflow triggers provides organizations with granular control over procurement approvals. These categories can now be defined as start conditions for purchase order workflows, allowing organizations to tailor approval processes based on financial responsibility and operational context. Additionally, step conditions can be configured to assign specific individuals responsible for each category, ensuring that approvals are targeted and relevant. This supports better financial stewardship and operational alignment.

 

For more information, see:  Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders

 

V4 API for intracompany stock transfer

SAP‚Äôs introduction of a new OData V4 API for intracompany stock transfers enables external applications to create, read, update, and delete stock transport orders in real time. This API-driven approach supports seamless integration with external systems, facilitating efficient stock movement across organizational units and enhancing data accuracy. The inclusion of error messaging ensures that invalid data is promptly flagged, reducing the risk of discrepancies and improving overall inventory control.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Stock Transport Order (CE_STOCKTRANSPORTORDER_0001) and Stock Transport Order (OData V4)

Maintenance of supplier confirmation notes

Supplier collaboration is enhanced through the automatic integration of supplier confirmation notes into purchase orders. When suppliers provide notes during the confirmation process, these are now automatically transferred to the corresponding purchase order and its items. This ensures that supplier input is accurately captured and reflected throughout the procurement lifecycle. By reducing manual data entry and minimizing the risk of miscommunication, this feature improves order accuracy and strengthens supplier relationships.

 

For more information, see: Manage Supplier Confirmations

Enable account assignment category Q in Manage Purchase Contracts App

Project-based procurement receives a boost with the inclusion of account assignment category Q (project stock) in the Manage Purchase Contract app. This enables organizations to handle make-to-order scenarios with greater precision, including the management of fields such as WBS elements and GL accounts. By extending support to project procurement, SAP empowers industries like construction, engineering, and manufacturing to align purchasing activities with project timelines and budgets.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see:  Manage Purchase Contracts

Extensibility in manage source lists app

The Manage Source List app has been enhanced to support custom fields, allowing users to store business-specific information that aids in sourcing decisions. Previously, the app did not permit the addition of custom fields, limiting its flexibility. With the new capability, users can define fields of various types‚Äîsuch as string, date, and decimal‚Äîand manage them using provided BADIs. This extensibility supports tailored data management and improves the efficiency of source list maintenance.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Source Lists and Overview of Changes in Extensibility Objects

Viewing distributed value still to be invoiced in the purchase order items by account assignment app

Financial transparency is further improved with the ability to view pending invoice values distributed across account assignment splits in purchase order items. When a purchase order item is assigned to multiple cost objects, such as cost centers or internal orders, users can now monitor the open invoice amount proportionally per assignment line. This granular visibility supports accurate accruals, budget tracking, and financial reporting, enabling organizations to maintain tighter control over their expenditures.

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Purchase Order Items by Account Assignment 

Procurement Expansion Package

The Procurement Expansion Package (PEP) consolidates advanced operational procurement features, catalog content channels, and supplier network capabilities into a single offering. Designed for SAP Cloud ERP customers, PEP delivers comprehensive spend coverage, improved compliance, and enhanced supplier collaboration. It supports a consumer-grade shopping experience, touchless supplier interactions, and end-to-end visibility across procurement processes. By digitizing manual transactions and centralizing procurement data, PEP helps organizations achieve greater efficiency, transparency, and strategic value.

 

For more information, see: Manage Central Purchase Contracts

 

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

Input tax ‚Äì Calculation, verification, and validation using external tax engines

Tax compliance is a critical aspect of procurement, and SAP addresses this through integration with external tax engines like Vertex and Thomson Reuters in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management. This integration allows for the calculation, verification, and validation of VAT, GST, and other transaction taxes on supplier invoices. By automating tax determination and comparison with supplier-provided data, organizations can prevent overpayments, mitigate compliance risks, and enhance audit readiness. The ability to specify commodity codes and use address data for tax calculation further refines the accuracy of this process.

 

 

For more information, see: Verification of Tax Applied to a Supplier Invoice

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP Ariba Central Procurement

Enablement of single-line distributions from central purchase contracts

Central procurement capabilities have been expanded in two key areas. First, the activation of single-line distribution within central contracts allows organizations to generate individual outline agreements for each contract line item. This is particularly beneficial for industries such as automotive, where scheduling agreements often require single-item configurations. Second, when copying a central contract, users can now edit fields such as supplier and purchasing organization, providing greater flexibility in contract lifecycle management and enabling smoother transitions when suppliers change.

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Central Purchase Contracts

entry.title: Let‚Äôs Talk About Clean Core
entry.content:
What is Clean Core?

In simple terms: Clean Core is the practice of keeping the core of SAP S/4HANA as ‚Äúclean‚Äù and standardized as possible.

This means avoiding heavy customizations directly in the system core and, instead, using extensions, APIs, and official tools provided by SAP. By doing so, your company can:

  • Upgrade the system with less effort.

  • Reduce maintenance costs.

  • Adopt innovations much faster.

üëâ More details here: SAP Clean Core Methodology

Why is this important?

In SAP ECC, it was common for companies to change the central code to meet specific needs. The result? A heavy, rigid system ‚Äî expensive to upgrade and always slowing down the move to the cloud.

Clean Core was born to break this cycle. It allows your company to take advantage of SAP‚Äôs continuous updates without the ‚Äúheadaches,‚Äù while staying agile enough to innovate.

A Simple Analogy: Tidying Up the House

Think about it like this:

  • If you organize your house the way Marie Kondo suggests ‚Äî everything in its place ‚Äî it‚Äôs much easier to keep order every day.

  • But if you only tidy up when guests arrive, you‚Äôll spend way more time and energy, and probably still leave things out of place.

Clean Core works the same way: you keep the system organized from the start, instead of ‚Äúfixing things‚Äù only when a new upgrade or version migration arrives.

So, Where Should You Customize?

Here‚Äôs the strategic insight: not everything needs customization.

Accounting reports, tax invoices, legal requirements‚Ä¶ these are standardized and can follow SAP‚Äôs market-ready models, especially in the Cloud Public Edition.

That frees up time and budget for what really matters: the processes that differentiate your business and make customers choose you.

And it‚Äôs there ‚Äî in these unique areas ‚Äî that you should apply business intelligence and customizations, using the right S/4HANA tools (such as in-app extensions or side-by-side developments on SAP BTP).

In Summary

Clean Core is more than a technical recommendation. It‚Äôs a system management philosophy:

  • Keep what is standard truly standard.

  • Customize only where your competitive advantage lies.

  • Always think about why your company exists and the value it delivers to customers.

That way, every update will be smooth, every innovation easier to adopt, and the company‚Äôs focus will remain on what creates real market impact.

Introduction

SAP has introduced the SAM4U solution, an excellent tool to gather data from SAP backend systems for the consolidation and analysis of users, engines, and HANA EE license consumption.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, available on SAP Store, provides extended analytics and simulation capabilities to view SAM4U data from new angles. What Was Missing?

While SAM4U provides valuable transparency, customers often asked:

  • How do I see the potential savings?

  • How do I define a strategy for optimization?

  • Where exactly should I focus my cleanup efforts?

License optimization typically falls into three categories:

  • Fast optimization: achieved quickly with user data cleanup in SAP backend

  • Obtainable optimization: achievable in reasonable time with cleanup and role/profile tuning

  • Maximal optimization: the long-term goal, achieved when roles and authorizations are precisely aligned with actual usage

The AI Assistant is always there, and expanding its knowledge base is straightforward through the Skybuffer AI platform. For example, it can present the top 10 roles for optimization or provide additional information related to SAP licensing:

Of course, all the well-established simulation and analysis tools of the Accelerator remain available. With the new release, they work even better, helping to test and simulate the AI Assistant‚Äôs recommendations.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption now provides one of the most powerful toolsets on the market to analyze and optimize SAP users and engines licenses independently. entry.title: Using the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Status App
entry.content:
SAP Note 1257308 - FAQ: Using EarlyWatch Alert provides preliminary information about the Status App. The app tracks the status of the SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) from the arrival of service data through all processing steps at SAP. This app is intended for administrators to troubleshoot the EWA process. This blog will provide a more detailed description of the Status App functionality.

EWA session data can be sent to SAP through various methods. The EWA session data can be sent directly to SAP through the HTTP destination SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL (via SAP-SUPPORT_PARCELBOX) from either an ABAP managed system or an SAP Solution Manager system. Additionally, any EWA session data for systems managed by the ECS team are sent via their SAP Focused Run systems on SAP side to be processed. The following Notes and KBAs are provided for more information on all three scenarios.

  • 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP
  • 1684537 - EarlyWatch Alert Not Sent to SAP: Troubleshooting Guide - SAP Solution Manager
  • 2930644 - SAP Focused Run: EarlyWatch Alert Troubleshooting Guide - Guided Answer

After sending EWA session data through one of the available methods it can be unclear whether the EWA data was successfully received by SAP or if there was any issue with the EWA session processing. The EWA Status App allows you to follow the status of your EWA report once it‚Äôs sent to SAP.

All EWA session data sent to SAP will be available for review in the EWA Status App, here you will find various details about the EWA sessions you have sent.

You can see the date the EWA session data session was sent, if they have been successfully received by SAP, as well as whether the EWA session could be processed successful or has been generated and posted in the EWA workspace.

Since the EWA session data packages sent to SAP are processed in randomly assigned batches for all customers it can take from a few hours to a few days for your EWA result to be available in various SAP applications like the EWA Workspace, Solution Finder, EWA Dashboard, or as a Word document available for download. Using the Status App allows you to track this process without opening a case.

The general fields available in the EWA Status App that are applicable for all system types are the following columns.

  • System
  • Product
  • Sending System Product
  • Data Received at SAP
  • Collected At

The ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù and ‚ÄúProduct‚Äù columns will list the long and short SID as well as the product version respectively of the EWA target system.

The ‚ÄúSending System Product‚Äù column, however, will display the product version of the system that transferred the session data to SAP. This is most often a Solution Manager or Focused Run system.  

Finally, the ‚ÄúData Received at SAP‚Äù and ‚ÄúCollected at‚Äù columns document the date and time the EWA session package was received by SAP as well as when it was collected on the managed system.

Data Transfer Status Details

In the EWA Status App the ‚ÄúData Transfer Status Details‚Äù column can have one of three status‚Äô. The status‚Äô are Rejected, Ignored, Success. As you would expect Success simply indicates the EWA session data was successfully transferred to SAP. The other two status‚Äô can be indicative of various errors. I will describe the most common in more detail below.

"Ignored (duplicate)"

This status indicates that the EWA is sent multiple times per week for the same system. You should check to see if the EWA is being sent from both Solution Manager and the managed system. The same checks should be performed for on prem FRUN systems. The EWA could also be sent multiple times per week from the same system. All will result in the same status.

"Ignored (not in allow list)"

This status can be caused by a few errors. However, the most common would be that either the license or maintenance certificate for the system is expired.

Recommendation:

Review the SLICENSE transaction in Solution Manager if used as well as the managed system to ensure both are up to date.

"Rejected (system time in future)"

The system runs with a system time deviating from official time. 

Recommendation:

The System Time can be synced manually by your system Admin. However, it is likely that this is a temporary change for testing purposes and it will sync automatically via Internet. If not working, your Admin can start this sync process at the OS Level.

 

"Rejected (no data)"

The service data that arrived at SAP is either not readable or empty or incomplete and thus important parts are completely missing.

Recommendation:

This would indicate that there are issues with EWA session data collection or service data quality. We recommend reviewing the resolution steps in the KBA 1824881 - Summary of Grey Rated EWA Reports - SAP Solution Manager.

"Rejected (non-productive)"

Only for productive and test systems the EWA is processed at SAP. Based on the system role the service data can be rejected. This is true for managed systems before ST-PI 740 SP23 (ST-PI 2008_1_7xx SP33) more information on the adjusted criteria can be found in SAP Note 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP.

"Rejected (not authorized)"

The technical communication user used for upload is not authorized to upload for this system.

Or

The technical communication user used for upload is not valid anymore.

Or

The user used for upload is not a technical communication user.

Recommendation:

You will need to ensure the S user assigned to both the SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL and SAP-SUPPORT_PACELBOX HTTP destinations is a valid technical user. The following KBA outlines the requirements for the assigned user.

2174416 - Creation and activation of Technical Communication Users - SAP for Me

"Rejected (other reason)"

Create a case with component SV-SCS-EWA-GEN.

"Rejected (content size exceeds limit)"

The service data exceeds the size limit.

"Rejected (unknown system type)"

Supported technical system types are ABAP, HANA, JAVA and BOBJ. When extracting the leading system from the service data either no technical system type was determined, or the technical system type is not supported by EarlyWatch Alert.

Recommendation:

If using Solution Manager it is recommended that you review the system information maintained in LMDB. Ensure the technical system type is maintained and that it is a supported type.

In addition, in some scenarios is may be required to replace the SDCCN service definitions. The following KBA outlines the process and under which circumstances these steps should be performed.

SAP KBA 1765141 - When should the Service Definitions be completely replaced (Delete and Download) using the steps outlined in SAP Note 727998?

"Rejected (data too old)"

The service data that was sent to SAP was collected more than 112 days ago. Such old service data is not processed by SAP.

 

Details on Report Status, Dashboard Status, and Solution Finder Status

These three columns are relatively binary. The Status can either be ‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù or ‚ÄúMissing‚Äù / blank. In rare instances you can receive the status ‚ÄúError (Initialization Failed)‚Äù. In this instance a case should be opened in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

The Report Status will be successful when the EWA document has been successfully generated. Until this point this column will remain blank. As mentioned previously it can take from a few hours to several days for your EWA result to be available. If the EWA session data was successfully received by SAP there is no cause for concern if the EWA report is not immediately available.

The same is true of the columns ‚ÄúDashboard Status‚Äù and ‚ÄúSolution Finder Status‚Äù. When these applications are fully populated the EWA column status here in the Status App will change to Success. Prior to this the status will remain either blank or have the status ‚ÄúMissing‚Äù. Neither status is a cause for concern. If after several days the status of these columns remains unpopulated you should open a case in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

 

2 Billion Record Limit Status and Number Range Forecast Details

This column is system dependent. These checks are in reference to the maximum table size for HANA systems. The maximum table size cannot exceed 2 billion records for a HANA system without detrimental impact to the system.

However, the status ‚ÄúMissing‚Äù is most often applied to systems that do not have a HANA component. This information is not relevant to your system if you do not have a HANA Component and is not a cause for concern. You should review the EWA for the affected system to confirm that there is no associated HANA DB.

For HANA systems where this check was not successfully performed the status will instead be ‚ÄúNo Forecast‚Äù, ‚ÄúPartial Success‚Äù, or ‚ÄúUnconfident Forecast‚Äù.

These may be a cause for concern and your first steps should be to review the RTCCTOOL recommendations of both the managed system and Solution Manager. You are looking for any red warning objects related to HANA session data, ST-PI, or ST-A/PI.

More information about the exact limitations of HANA are documented in the KBA 2154870 - How-To: Understanding and defining SAP HANA Limitations.

Additionally, more information can be found in the HANA Sizing Blog.

entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP¬¥s ready-to-run public Cloud ERP software solution. SAP S/4HANS Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem ‚Äì customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

Managing a skilled workforce efficiently is paramount for any growing organization. With the release 2508 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, businesses are empowered with robust HR connectivity options, which streamline workforce management activities. This article provides guidance on handling workforce data, work agreements, and user management using various technical integration options.

In traditional Identity Management (IDM) scenarios, HR systems usually take the lead in managing worker data and work agreements. Business user data might be managed directly in an IDM system or integrated via an HR system. The culmination of these processes sees the provisioning of worker data, work agreements, and business user data into the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant through effective HR and IDM integration. Successful workforce management in this landscape hinges on strategic decisions about data creation through HR or IDM integration, based on which system leads.

 

Results: Realizing Workforce Management Scenarios


Imagine a scenario where SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is integrated with both the SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (using SAP Master Data Integration for HR) and an external IDM system via SOAP-based integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services. Here, aligning IDM integration as the leading choice brings forth several advantages.

 

Define Workforce Management System and Choose an Integration Option

  • IDM Integration Leads: Creating business user and worker data first allows users to access the system and perform tasks without needing pre-established work agreements.
  • HR Integration Leads: Worker data and work agreements are provisioned first, followed by business user creation, ensuring structured data flow.

To configure your scenario, access SAP Central Business Configuration for your specific tenant, locate the Define Workforce Management Scenario (106757) activity, and select your desired option: HR integration (default) or IDM integration. Currently, the default is ‚ÄúManage worker data using HR integration.‚Äù In this scenario, workforce data and work assignments must already exist in SAP S/4HANA Cloud through HR integration before business users can be created and assigned via IDM integration. The alternative ‚ÄúManage worker data using IDM integration‚Äù scenario allows the creation of workforce persons directly with the provisioning of user accounts through IDM integration, so business users can log in and perform tasks even before a work assignment is provided. The work assignment can then be provisioned later via the HR channel if required.

Please note: At this stage, the IDM-driven scenario is only available to customers participating in the Early Adopter Care (EAC) Program. If you are interested, alignment with the EAC Program Leads is required.

 

Flexible Data Management

With the integration setup, you can create worker and business user data within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition through the integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services or manually via the Manage Workforce or Maintain Business Users apps. However, once data is created through integration, it cannot be modified directly in these apps. The Entry Source field denotes where data can be edited and its origin. Refer to the Entry Source documentation for further information. If establishing a work agreement through HR integration precedes the creation of a worker record, an error will occur.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers businesses with flexible HR connectivity options for workforce management. By carefully selecting and implementing integration strategies, organizations can achieve efficient operations and seamless data management, essential for navigating the complex terrain of modern business environments. entry.title: Simulation for SAM4U Solution: Flexibility with the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption
entry.content:
When adopting SAP SAM4U, one of the biggest challenges customers face is handling role, profile, and authorization changes without disrupting production. This is where the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings real value, thanks to its simulation capabilities.

What Customers Expect from Authorization Simulation

With the simulation, customers get the ability to:

  • Log changes at the role or profile level on the system dataset.
  • Track and review roles and profiles that have been modified.
  • Revert changes at the role or profile level, either all at once or individually.
  • Modify user-to-role or user-to-profile assignments.
  • Perform mass unassignments of roles and profiles (e.g., removing SAP_ALL or SAP_NEW).
  • Identify and review changes made to users.
  • Revert user assignments back to their original state when needed.

 Pic. 01 Roles and Profiles Changes Tracking

 Pic. 02 Roles and Profiles Mass Unassignment

 Pic. 03 Changes to the Role Detailed Review

But that‚Äôs not all! The real power lies in managing simulation snapshots.

 Pic. 04 Snapshots of Simulations on the System‚Äôs Dataset Level

Why Simulation Snapshots Matter

Simulation snapshots are created at the system dataset level, allowing you to:

  • Save changes without applying them directly in production.
  • Create new consolidations from modified datasets.
  • Avoid repetitive, time-consuming rework when changes cannot be applied immediately.

Example: Working with Two Systems in Consolidation

Imagine you are analyzing two systems in a consolidation project. You make changes to roles and users in both systems. However, due to restrictions, you cannot yet apply changes in System A.

Without losing your work, you can:

  • Create a new consolidation using the dataset from System A and the modified snapshot from System B.
  • Or temporarily move the snapshot from System A into the dataset, and later reapply those changes when they are ready for production.

 Pic. 05 The Power of Management Snapshots and Datasets that are Used in Consolidation

This flexibility ensures you never have to redo your work and can manage changes efficiently.

Why Customers Prefer the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption

Customers appreciate the simulation feature because it provides:

  • System-level flexibility to manage changes.
  • Easy-to-handle snapshots that can be created, reviewed, reverted, and reused.
  • No duplication of effort, once a change is made, it is saved and can be reapplied.
  • Reliable validation, you can reload fresh production data and check if changes were successfully implemented.

If changes were tracked only at the consolidation level, fresh data from the system would overwrite them. This is why the Accelerator focuses on system snapshots, giving customers full control to experiment, validate, and roll back whenever needed.

 Pic.06 Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption Dashboard for Simulation Results Analysis

With the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, simulation becomes not just a test environment, but a strategic tool for efficient and risk-free SAM4U adoption.

entry.title: The Importance of Cross-Module Knowledge for SAP Consultants
entry.content:
The Importance of Cross-Module Knowledge for SAP Consultants

In today‚Äôs dynamic SAP landscape, being a consultant means much more than mastering your own module. As a functional consultant in SAP MM, I‚Äôve learned over the years that success in real projects often depends on how well you understand the integration points with other modules.

   Why Cross-Module Knowledge Matters

End-to-End Processes: Business processes rarely stop at one module. A purchase order in MM eventually impacts FI through accounting entries, SD when linked to sales, and PP when it involves production. Without cross-module awareness, consultants risk missing critical dependencies.

Better Communication with Teams: Projects bring together FI, SD, PP, WM, and other consultants. Knowing their language and challenges helps avoid misunderstandings and ensures smoother collaboration.

Problem-Solving: Many issues reported by end users appear to be ‚ÄúMM problems,‚Äù but in reality, they stem from integration‚Äîsuch as GR/IR mismatches (MM‚ÄìFI), stock discrepancies (MM‚ÄìWM), or subcontracting issues (MM‚ÄìPP). A consultant with cross-module knowledge can resolve issues faster.

   Key Integration Areas for MM Consultants

MM‚ÄìFI: Inventory valuation, account determination, invoice verification.

MM‚ÄìSD: Third-party order processing, intercompany stock transfers.

MM‚ÄìPP: Material requirements planning, subcontracting, and production orders.

MM‚ÄìWM/EWM: Goods receipt, stock placement, and picking processes.

    Benefits for Your Career

Stronger Profile: Recruiters and clients look for consultants who can think beyond one module.

Added Value: You become a bridge between teams, often reducing delays in projects.

Future-Readiness: In SAP S/4HANA, processes are even more integrated, making cross-module knowledge a must-have skill.

    How to Build Cross-Module Skills

Learn from your colleagues on projects‚Äîask questions, join design workshops.

Explore integration scenarios in a training or sandbox system.

Follow SAP documentation and blogs focused on cross-functional processes.

Share knowledge within your teams and communities to reinforce your learning.

 

Final Thought: Mastering your own module is essential, but expanding into cross-module knowledge transforms you from a ‚Äúconsultant‚Äù into a true process expert. In the end, it‚Äôs not just about configuring SAP,it‚Äôs about understanding and optimizing business processes end to end.

entry.title: From Customer Org. Chart to SAP Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus,
While diving deep into the world of SAP ERP for over 10 years, I wanted to share some of my findings and experience on a topic that can be a challenge for many of us: How to Design the Customer‚Äôs Organization Hierarchy into SAP Enterprise Structure.

It's great to deploy what the SAP best practice says, but from the customer perspective it‚Äôs very sensitive step as it‚Äôs reflecting the overall business decisions. I recognized this during my career in implementing SAP projects, and I hope my findings can help you out there for whom might be starting on a similar journey.

Bridging the Gap Between Customer's Org. Chart and SAP Enterprise Structure

We all have our company's organizational chart hanging somewhere in the office or in a PowerPoint file. It shows the customer's department hierarchy, who reports to whom, and how teams are structured.

But how do we take that familiar hierarchy and map it to SAP's world of Company Codes, Plants, and Purchasing Organizations? It's not always a one-to-one match, and that's where the complexity (and honestly, the fun!) begins.

I found an example of this in old SAP Community question from 2008. A community user laid out a detailed case study of a company with 4 factories, 3 regional distribution centers, 15 sales offices, in addition of an R&D team and project management team. It was a fantastic real world scenario that highlighted the tough question we often face.

"since material from Plant and RDC is being transferred to Branches and from there it is distributed to customers therefore the valuation of FG at BRANCH and RDC should be different as transportation cost, packing, unpacking etc cost should get added at Branch level. Therefore in case I make branch as Storage location, I will miss the valuation part while if I make them as Plant then there will be lot of documents get generated for each movement."

This is exactly the kind of practical dilemma that gets to the heart of enterprise structure design. It's a constant balancing act between financial accuracy and operational efficiency.

Understanding The SAP Organizational Units

Before we define and assign the SAP enterprise structure, we need to know exactly what of each SAP org. unit represents. It‚Äôs helpful to think of them in a hierarchical way, starting from the top.

  1. Client: the highest level in the SAP system hierarchy. Specifications that you make, or data that you enter at this level are valid for all company codes and for all other organizational structures. You therefore only need to make these specifications, or enter this data once. This ensures that the data is consistent.
  2. Company Codes: is the central organizational unit of external accounting within the SAP System. You must define at least one company code before implementing the Financial Accounting component. The business transactions relevant for Financial Accounting are entered, saved, and evaluated at company code level.
  3. Plant: organizational unit serving to subdivide an enterprise according to production, procurement, maintenance, and materials planning aspects. It is a place where either materials are produced or goods and services provided.
  4. Purchasing Organizations and Purchasing Groups: An organizational unit subdividing an enterprise according to the requirements of Purchasing. It procures materials and services, negotiates conditions of purchase with vendors, and is responsible for such transactions. A purchasing group is a key for a buyer or group of buyers in SAP ERP. It is responsible for the procurement of a material or class of materials, and is the principal channel for a company's dealings with its suppliers.

Organizational Unit

Key Characteristics

Typical Use Cases

Client

Highest level, represents entire corporate group

One per SAP system

Company Code

Legal entity with independent financial statements

Subsidiaries, country operations

Plant

Operational unit where business activities occur

Factories, warehouses, sales offices

Storage Location

Physical storage area within a Plant

Warehouse sections, storage areas

Purchasing Org

Defines procurement scope and authority

Centralized or decentralized procurement

My Key Takeaways and Learned Lessons

After implementing a lot of SAP projects, here are some advices I have heard from my leaders:

Start with the "Why," Not the "What." Don't just create organizational units because they exist in your company. Think about your business processes and reporting requirements first. What do the customer need to see in his financial reports? How he manage his inventory? How do he want to analyze his procurement activities and expenses? The answers to these questions should guide you WHAT is the correct design decisions.

  1. The Plant is probably the most versatile org. unit in SAP. I've seen Plants used to represent everything from manufacturing facilities to service centers. Don't be afraid to think creatively about how to use Plants to model your business operations. Just remember that each Plant needs to be assigned to a Company Code, so plan accordingly. And remember that SAP defines the plant as a logistics organizational element that is used by all the logistics modules. The plant is assigned to a company code that may have many plants assigned to it. A plant is typically configured in conjunction with the company code and valuation area due to tax rules and regulations.
    Depending on the role the plant has in the organization, a plant can be defined for the following purposes:
    • In Sales and Distribution (SD), a location from which finished goods and materials are stored and distributed.
    • A location from which services are rendered.
    • Materials Management (MM), a location where material flow is managed and stock requirements are managed from both the inbound and outbound perspectives.
    • A location where material stock is consumed, planned, and purchased.
    • A manufacturing facility where materials are produced, as in Production Planning (PP).
  2. Purchasing org. structure has a huge impact on your procurement processes, approval workflows, and reporting. I learned that the hard way when we had to redesign our purchasing structure because we hadn't thought through the implications properly. Take time to understand whether a centralized or decentralized org. unit makes the most sense for your company.
  3. Plan for Growth and Change, Your first design probably won't be perfect, and your business will expand over time. Build flexibility into your design where possible, and don't be afraid to iterate, I've seen too many implementations get stuck because they tried to create the "perfect" structure from day one instead of starting with something good and improving it over time.
  4. Document Your Decisions, This might seem obvious, but document not just what you designed, but why you designed it. think in future questions, when someone ask why the regional sales offices are defined as plants instead of storage locations, you'll be glad that you wrote your reasoning.

Important Considerations

in past implementations i've encountered some comments from the customer that might help you think through your own design:

  1. Multi-Country Operations: If the customer operates in multiple countries, you'll likely need separate company codes for each country due to legal and tax requirements, but you might be able to share plants across company codes for operational efficiency.
  2. Shared Transactions: If the customer has shared service centers (like a centralized IT department or shared warehouse), think carefully about how to define and assign these on SAP, sometimes they're best represented as separate org. units, sometimes as cost centers within existing org. units.
  3. Acquisitions and Divestitures: If the company invest in other legal entities by frequently acquires or divests business units, design the SAP structure to make these transitions easier, this might mean keeping acquired companies as separate company codes initially, even if the customer plan to integrate them later.

Summery

SAP Enterprise Structure design is a piece of art, a part of business administration science, and a part of overall company growth.
There's no one "correct" way to do it, but there are definitely wrong ways, the key here is to understand customer business requirements, think through the implications of your design, and be prepared to adapt as you may learn later.
